title: NPC Streaming | Know Your Meme

NPC Streaming, also known as NPC Trend, is a type of TikTok LIVE stream in which the streamer acts or is perceived as acting like a video game NPC by mimicking idle animations, only saying something or performing a specific action when gifted, the action or phrase changing depending on the gift.

title: Counter-gaming | Alexander R. Galloway

highlights.highlight: RTS games focus on a multi-nodal ecosystem of flows and factories, resources and expenditures, secure zones and hostile frontiers. The RTS genre is thus informatic capitalism pure and simple. The genre displays how informatic media and informatic labor are essentially coterminous in todayâs world.

A somewhat nefarious miasma lingers in all of this, for the labor of the web surfer or the gamer or the blogger goes unpaid, even while exploited by other parties. Thus within the sphere of gaming, we are obligated to come to terms with a new kind of unpaid labor, a new kind of economy.

labor today is often simply donated as a âgiftâ to the economy. This will be the ultimate tragic denouement of the rise of gaming, of the democratization of play, of social media, of open-source software: it will result in the open-sourcing of all labor; the demand for âvolunteerâ workers will metastasize across all spheres of public life.
The Web is, in this sense, the world's largest sweat shop, for it is the site of most unpaid labor in the world today.

To formulate this same observation in psychoanalytic terminology: previous mass media formats -- cinema famously -- were fundamentally masochistic; new media however are fundamentally sadistic, in that they require the labor of manipulation, selection, transformation and command over objects (data objects, commodities, behaviors, life forms, and of course other human beings)
In this way, if previous media formats disciplined human beings into becoming better workers, todayâs informatic media liberate human beings so they may become better bosses

remember how Brain Age for the Nintendo DS was all the rage a few years ago. In years to come we will see a steady rise in games devoted to informatic therapy and training. This is but one harbinger of the coming gamic class being cultivated today.

Hence a lament for the new informatic masters: we desperately need alternative algorithms; we desperately need counter-gaming. But, thus far, alternative algorithms seem hopelessly impossible, beyond the very horizon of intelligibility.
These days play looks more like labor, and labor looks more like play.
We still need alternative algorithms, now more than ever. But what would such algorithms look like?

The alternative algorithms of countergaming are either structured as negation or as deprivation. With negation, the game is stripped of all possibilities of game play, left to lapse back to other media altogether (video, animation). With deprivation, the game is censored and scolded, allowed to continue to play, but only in an enlightened or âself-awareâ mode.
the very essence of what makes a game a game is withheld, deferred either for all time, or just for a moment.

For one must never forget that there is an important utopian possibility contained within any type of aesthetic failure. Or as Jean-Jacques Rousseau wrote in his âDiscourse on the Arts and Sciencesâ of 1750: failure has an infinity of forms, but the truth is singular.
Today we should take this as a celebration not a lament, and focus on the failure not the truth. Counter-gaming shall have an infinity of forms.
let's demilitarize play; let's uncouple gaming from the mandates of the market; let's dial up the game studies and dial down the game theory.

title: LUDIC HAUNTOLOGY, DEFERRED CONNECTION | VRAL

highlights.highlight: Though formally dissimilar, both use video games not as entertainment or spectacle but to show how the political and the affective are routed through simulationâs infrastructural systems

Giath Tahaâs Becoming a Ghost (2022), screened on VRAL between August 30 and September 12 2023, documents a virtual reunion between two brothers separated by war and exile. Set entirely within PlayerUnknownâs Battlegrounds (PUBG), the work resists violence, focusing instead on acts of wandering, care, and quiet resistance.

Jonathan Milletâs Les fantÃ´mes (Ghost Trail, 2024) is a thriller centred on Hamid (Adam Bessa), a Syrian exile in Strasbourg, who uses a multiplayer war game to update members of an underground network about the whereabouts of an alleged former torturer now living under an assumed identity

the video game in FantÃ´mes functions as an infrastructure of concealment: a camouflaged protocol where violence is simulated and strategic operations are hidden in plain sight. Hamid and his cohort do not play for recreation; using assumed names, they track fugitives and share updates during multiplayer sessions. The interfaceâavatars, voice chat, and devastated environmentsâallows for identity checks and coordinated actions while maintaining plausible deniability
the gameâs internal logic mirrors the asylum process: action must follow verification, and haste may unravel everything

The procedural structure of the game substitutes for institutions and bureaucracy, while replicating their opacity and constraint. If the game appears as a high-intensity third-person shooter, the real stakes it obscures are calculated, protracted, and deeply consequential
Where Les fantÃ´mes prioritises verification and delay, Taha suspends those logics entirely
Becoming a Ghost offers a starkly different use of the game architecture and interface
He does not aim to win or deceive, conquer or destroy, but to remain present with his brother
Becoming a Ghost suspends that logic, opting instead for ambient drift and affective openness through counter-gaming

The so-called âmagic circleâ collapses here: rather than an insulated sphere of norms, outcomes and make-believe, the game functions as a real-time infrastructure for personal and collective manoeuvre

title: VRAL 93: Giath Taha â MILAN MACHINIMA FESTIVAL

highlights.highlight: Separated for ten years due to the Syrian conflict, Taha and his brother reconnect in this digital warzone, which mirrors the real-life violence that forced Taha to flee Syria. Although the game involves players competing to be the last one standing, it paradoxically becomes a safe space for the brothers to discuss topics censored elsewhere. The work explores themes of presence and absence, reality and simulation, and how virtual spaces can offer temporary escape from harsh realities

The relationship between video gaming and geopolitical issues is deeply intertwined and layered. Many games are set in real locations or engage with real geopolitical tensions, often as a form of soft power, cultural influence, or even propaganda

PUBG, its popularity in Syria can be attributed to two main factors. Firstly, the gameâs graphics are relatively modest compared to the sound design, meaning that players donât need high-end devices like the Xbox Series X or PlayStation 5 to participate â a typical mobile phone is sufficient. This accessibility is crucial

PUBGâs popularity lies in the lived experiences of players. Many of them are profoundly affected by the geopolitical realities of the Middle East, including the oppressive conditions in Syria. For these players, PUBG offers an escape â a shift from a dystopian reality controlled by oppressors to a virtual space that, while similar, provides an alternative existence. Itâs a way to momentarily leave behind the harsh realities of their surroundings
This desire to escape is why so many players bring their backgrounds and political realities into the game
virtual world becomes a place to process, and perhaps temporarily avoid, the oppressive situations they face daily
From Heideggerâs perspective, being is not fully present in any single moment. Itâs an interplay of presence and absence, involving both the past and the present
Derrida, on the other hand, argues that presence is never fully attainable; itâs always deferred through a chain of signifiers, making his approach more linguistic
Building on these ideas, being thrown into a war zone and being distracted by the manifestations of conflict allows authenticity to emerge

I consciously chose not to fight or engage in what the game â or the platform â demanded of me. The authenticity of the other person, in this case, my brother, also surfaced in this context. He used to play the game almost daily, but when we met online after twelve years, the game transformed for him. It became less about playing and more about protecting his younger brother, who had annoyingly decided not to carry a weapon in a shooting game
To tie this back to Heidegger, the moment was an interplay between presence and absence

I think itâs crucial to remember that video games, especially online ones, are essentially interactive systems. The designers set up the rules, defining the framework within which players can operate. This setup often limits the players' freedom, making them subject to the designersâ choices. In a way, this can resemble a form of authoritarian control. Players can interact with the game, but only within the confines of the system, leading to specific actions and predetermined outcomes
I completely agree with your observation that video games are promoted as open worlds â spaces of possibilities and freedom

The line between virtuality and reality is very thin, and I didnât want to be trapped by the same mechanisms of control. So, my defense mechanism was to be a pacifist in the game, resisting what the gameâs designers expected me to do.
When players engage with video games, they seek an alternative virtual space, but they inevitably bring their real-life complexities with them

important aspect of gaming is its immersive experience. However, this immersion is temporary â it doesnât last forever. Thatâs why escapism is not absolute or definitive; itâs transient and limited, often ending when players return to their real lives

In his âState of Cinemaâ address at the 46th San Francisco Film Festival, French critic Michel Ciment (2003) described the emergence of a new cinematic style,Â âa cinema of slowness, of contemplationâ. One year later, British critic Jonathan Romney coined the now popular expression âSlow Cinemaâ in a review to indicate those films that deliberately reject the narrative and aesthetic conventions of mainstream productions (1)
Slow cinema emphasizes long takes and extended durations. Observational in nature, it uses subdued visual techniques and minimal narrative strategies.

âThe plot and dialogue in slow movies often gravitate towards stillness and death, and tend, in any case, to be minimal, indeterminate and unresolvedâ (p. 23)

Lav Diaz, Pedro Costa, Lisandro Alonso, Ben Rivers, Carlos Reygadas, Bela Tarr, Apichatpong Weerasethakul, Tsai Ming-liang, Kelly Reichardt

âslow machinimaâ is an international effort, fiercely independent, and deliberately adversarial to the dominant paradigm. Slow machinima productions are generally indifferent or deliberately antagonistic to mainstream game audiences, and perhaps, to mainstream audiences in general.
In many ways, slow machinima is a gesture of coordinated resistance to contemporary game culture and its testosterone-driven aesthetics, hype cycles, and overt misogyny.

In its rejection of gaming instant gratification, slow machinima chronicles the spaces and times of inactivity and âin-betweennessâ of mainstream productions, those sparse moments of tranquility of otherwise fast and furious âtriple AAA titlesâ or âfranchisesâ

If most video games can be situated in the accelerationist paradigm - itself a manifestation of capitalismâ obsession for growth, speed, and grotesque excess - slow machinima invokes a more reflective, attentive, and introspective viewing experience

Our attention spans shrink toward zero because we have to make too many decisions within ever shorter windows of time.
